Comment: We open up our kings' pawns to free our queens or kingside bishops...
We open up our kings' pawns to free our queens or kingside bishops...
...and I free my other bishop...
...and I free my other bishop...
...then we trade pawns...
...then we trade pawns...
...and as he develops his knight...
...my queen retreats.
He moves his second-left pawn (aka b-pawn), no doubt hoping to fianchetto his bishop...
...so my knight comes up to give my king's pawn extra cover. (This pawn had not moved since my first move; the pawn I lost was my queen's pawn.)
His light-square bishop attacks my queen...
...so I move her forwards...
...and is pressured by his second right pawn (aka g-pawn)...
...so she retreats.
He moves his right flank pawn (aka h-pawn)...
...and I advance my knight, hoping to fork the king and rook...
...but his queen's pawn sees to that.
So I develop my light-square bishop to pressure his (as capturing it would mean no need to distort my pawn structure; my queen could recapture)...
...but the kingside rook's pawn places the queen under attack...
...so she moves to the only safe place.
My opponent attacks her with his bishop, but it had no support...
...so my queen accepts the gift...
...and although the knight attacks her...
